But in principle shouldn't the evaluation of the opponent be taken 
into account implicitly by the neural network?  Of course since that 
may not happen in practice perhaps it's worth looking into 
separating out the identification of opponent types.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> wrote:
> Derek James wrote:
> 
> >On 8/4/05, Ian Badcoe <ian_badcoe@y...> wrote:
> >  
> >
> >>At 14:31 04/08/2005, you wrote:
> >>
> >>But for TTT?  You don't need to know anything about the 
opponent.  
> >>    
> >>
> >
> >[...]
> >
> >If you know that your opponent is an optimal player, then you 
should
> >simply play for a tie.  If you know your opponent is suboptimal, 
it is
> >always beneficial to know that they are suboptimal, and even 
moreso to
> >know their particular weaknesses so that you can exploit them.
> >  
> >
> This is an  important aspect to consider, especially going forward 
> looking at other more complex games. In fact it's absolutely 
crucial for 
> some (most?) types of game. At this point in time though I favour 
> factoring out this aspect of gameplay by assuming no knowledge of 
an 
> opponent. Given this stipulation what is a perfect player?  A 
perfect 
> player must assume that the opponent is strong, and therefore must 
play 
> defensively whilst trying to keep winning lines open as a 
secondary goal 
> only - and only making a winning move if the opportunity arises.
> 
> Evaluating against defensive players will only give defensive 
players at 
> best - they won't know to make a winning line if the opportunity 
arises, 
> except out of pure luck maybe. So a perfect player (with no 
opponent 
> knowledge) is defensive but also knows how to win, thus a range of 
poor 
> to good strategies need to be represented during evaluation.
> 
> Colin
